title: Sad end as anti-racism AFL star Adam Goodes asked not to be considered for player award
text:
Sad end as anti-racism AFL star Adam Goodes asked not to be considered for player award LARISSA NICHOLSON Last updated 17:26, October 6 2015 CAMERON SPENCER/GETTY IMAGES 
Adam Goodes of the Swans celebrates kicking a goal earlier this season. 
Adam Goodes has asked to not be considered for an AFL Players Association award that recognises retiring players for their contribution to the sport and broader community. 
The Sydney Swans champion was named Australian of the Year in 2014 for taking a stand against racism and for his work with Indigenous youth. 
But the career of the two-time Brownlow medallist finished on a low note, after fans of other clubs booed Goodes at matches throughout 2015 - abuse that was widely condemned and considered motivated at least in part by racism. 
Goodes chose not to take part in the lap of honour for retiring champions at Saturday's grand final - won by Hawthorn over West Coast - and the AFL's Players Association on Tuesday said he had also asked not to be considered for the Madden Medal. 
The AFLPA lists criteria for the honour, which will be awarded in Melbourne on Friday, as football achievement, personal development and community spirit, and off-field engagement. 
This year's finalists are Carlton's Chris Judd, Dustin Fletcher and Paul Chapman from Essendon, Fremantle's Luke McPharlin, Daniel Cross from Melbourne, Kane Cornes from Port Adelaide and Chris Newman of Richmond. 
Previous winners have included Glenn Archer, Cameron Ling and Lenny Hayes.
